tree.description: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999

root.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
root.pub-comments: “On the basis of unambiguous evidence of exclusively shared innovations the Formosan languages appear to belong to no fewer than nine primary branches of the Austronesian family” (Blust 1999:31).
root.geography: all Formosan languages spoken on Taiwan
root.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: For evidence supporting a Tsouic subgroup, see Tsuchida 1976.
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: “The Rukai languages form a highly distinct group, particularly from the standpoint of syntax” (Blust 1999:51)
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: “All in all, then, the evidence for a Puyumic subgroup which includes Puyuma and Paiwan is far from convincing, given the evidence for longstanding borrowing, and for now it is best to consider each of these languages a primary branch of the An [Austronesian] family” (Blust 1999:51).
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: Blust states that the East Formosan languages share a unique sound change, the merger of *j and *n, and that “no other language, inside or outside Taiwan, has undergone this phonemic merger” (1999:46).
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: “The Atayalic subgroup is regarded as self-evident, and has been adequately demonstrated in e.g., Li (1981)” (Blust 1999:46).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: “It now seems reasonably clear that Thao must be added as a member of this group, although its exact position within it remains undecided (Blust 1996a)” (Blust 1999:52). “What is of interest for present purposes is that Thao appears to share certain lexical innovations exclusively with one of more of the WP [Western Plains] languages” (Blust 1996:279).
child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Subgrouping, Circularity and Extinction: Some Issues in Austronesian Comparative Linguistics, Selected Papers from the Eighth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, vol. 1, 31-94. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office). , Blust, Robert A. 1996. Some Remarks on the Linguistic Position of Thao, Oceanic Linguistics, 2 edn., vol. 35, 272-294.

child.publications: Blust, Robert A. 1999. Taipei, Taiwan: Symposium Series of the Institute of Linguistics (Preparatory Office).

child.tree-val: Formosan subgroups of Austronesian: Blust 1996 and 1999
child.pub-comments: “All in all, then, the evidence for a Puyumic subgroup which includes Puyuma and Paiwan is far from convincing, given the evidence for longstanding borrowing, and for now it is best to consider each of these languages a primary branch of the An [Austronesian] family” (Blust 1999:51).
